awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  In-pixel, real-time neural digitizer to restore connectivity in spinal cord injuries
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to improve the quality of life for people who suffer from debilitating forms of paralysis by restoring their lost functionality. There are 5.4 million people in the United States who suffer from paralysis. Not only do these patients suffer from the physical pain that comes with their condition but also, they are afflicted by financial and psychological burdens. The prostheses that are being used today are either passive and affordable or active and unaffordable for the majority of these patients. Active prostheses represent the forefront of brain-computer interfaces development. Current protheses suffer from drawbacks such as constant patient training, the necessity for bulky skin electrodes, variability in electrode positioning, and limited efficacy when worn and operated by the patients themselves. This device first targets incomplete paralysis by functioning as a neural relay station that bridges the disconnect between the healthy neural section above and below the site of injury.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project seeks to overcome the limitations of current brain-computer interfaces to not only restore functionality in people with paralysis, but to recreate a real-time, seamless experience for them. Most available neural probes rely on highly invasive, sharp shanks to penetrate neural tissue.  These probes cause considerable inflammation, ultimately leading to device failure. Current devices detect signals extracellularly which leads to a  low signal-to-noise ratio making signal extraction very challenging. This project will improve brain-computer interfaces by introducing nanoarchitecture to the sensing electrode in order to achieve intracellular sensing. This sensing dramatically increases the signal-to-noise ratio making signal extraction considerably simpler. This device is based on an active pixel complementary metal oxide semiconductor architecture which will turn neural signals into a string of ones and zeros making signal extraction considerably simpler. This process will minimize the patient-interface training time. This project will fabricate three-dimensional, nano-architected sensing electrodes with high-aspect ratio and high-density nanoneedles, mimicking the natural neural cell environment. The nanoneedles spontaneously penetrate neurons, achieve superior intracellular recording, and reduce chronic inflammation to promote device longevity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
There are 5.4 million people in the United States who suffer from debilitating forms of paralysis, more than 20,000 new cases occur every year. When a complete spinal cord injury occurs, the communication between the brain and limbs is interrupted and the patient loses sensory and motor control over their body. Over the last decade there?s been a boom in neurotechnology innovation with several startups such as Paradromics, Synchron and Precision Neuroscience that have made huge strides toward the production of commercial brain machine interfaces. Despite the impressive progress, most neurotech startups focus on the brain, targeting complex cortical networks which require elaborate schemes for deciphering brain signals and large data rates to transfer massive amounts of information from the brain to the computing unit. The major limitations of cortical devices are inherent to the brain?s architecture which is comprised of billions of neurons that are connected through an extremely complex three-dimensional network that is only partially mapped. For example, any given cortical neuron synapse is often competing with thousands of other excitatory and inhibitory neuron synapses. Due to this competitive complexity, recording from any given neuron fails to provide a sufficient, absolute value signal. As a result, a relatively large body of neurons needs to be interrogated to enable deciphering of neuronal patterns that are ultimately associated with a target behavior. Consequently, forming a behavioral-neural interface match involves significant patient participation with a medical team, which is time consuming, computationally expensive, power hungry, and heavily reliant on patient compliance.

By contrast, with the three-dimensionality of the brain, communication within the white matter of the spinal cord happens in one-dimension (e.g., up/down) and is discrete (e.g., no competing synapses within the white matter). In particular, the white matter of the spinal cord is mostly composed of a set of one-way channels that connect the brain and periphery, which makes movement and sensation possible. The major carriers of motor and sensory information in the spinal cord are axon bundles which are organized in tracts that form a regional map of the body. For example, pressure applied to the big toe is relayed to the brain via a medial region of the fasciculus gracilis, while motion of the shoulder is localized in the medial region of the lateral cortico-spinal tract. As a result of this intrinsic map provided by the spinal cord, signal decoding becomes drastically easier than in the cerebral cortex, leading to minimal patient-interface training, which greatly simplifies the adoption of spinal interfaces. We aim at building a spinal-cord-machine-interface (SCMI) which will be implanted in the white matter of paralyzed patients and bridge the communication between the patient?s brain and their limbs.

This phase I award allowed us to develop and de-risk the key components of our interface. We were able to fabricate implantable, shank probes with a small form factor (2 x 0.4 x 0.1mm) which incorporated an internal reference that cuts out unwanted local field potentials and further improves on device compactness which minimizes tissue inflammation. We also explored different electrode topography and coating materials which led to the development of optimal Pt-coated, low impedance protruding electrodes which were able to consistently record spinal cord activity with a signal to noise ratio of ~40dB.

Our probes were implanted in a rat?s spinal cord where they could record action potentials of varying amplitudes based on whether the rat was being mechanically stimulated or not. We were able to use our probes to successfully map different body locations onto the of the rat? spinal cord, which is the first crucial step toward building the first bi-directional, closed-loop SCMI. Additionally, this award allowed us to design and fabricate a CMOS sensing probe which is able to amplify and binarize compound action potentials that are the communication signatures of behaviors in the spinal cord. Unlike other brain interfaces that are developing the equivalent of a high-resolution color-display television, which offers unnecessary details for engineering applications, we were able to develop a chip that is able to capture a black and white map of spinal cord activity in real time. The next step in our project aims at turning the technology that we developed thanks to this award into a tangible, commercial, medical device. Most paralyzed patients suffer from neurogenic bladder which is the complete loss of control over one?s bladder leading to incontinence and frequent hospitalizations due to recurring infections. We aim to build a bi-directional, closed-loop bladder control device which combines our intraspinal probes and well-established sacral nerve stimulators so that patients will not only regain the ability to volitionally urinate, but more importantly they will be able to sense bladder filling which can drastically improve continence in addition to re-establishing some form of normalcy in the patient?s micturition habits.

Images (1 of )
  • We fabricated passive implantable probes with lengths varying from 1.5-3.5mm, widths of 0.4mm and thickness of less than 100um to minimize tissue damage. Both flat and micro-patterned electrodes were fabricated to investigate whether micro-pillars could achieve higher signal to noise ratio.
    Alessandro Maggi
    Public Domain
    Alessandro Maggi
    Implantable Passive Probes
  • We fabricated nano-sized pillars with diameter ranging from ~100-500nm and heights ranging from 1.5-5um to investigate whether intracellular sensing could be achieved in in-vivo environments.
    Alessandro Maggi
    Public Domain
    Alessandro Maggi
    Nanopillar Electrode Array
  • We designed a CMOS chip which is able to detect and digitize into 1 bit information action potentials so that we could build a real-time, "black and white" map of the neural activity of the spinal cord. We post processed the chips to release implantable shanks and coat the electrodes with Platinum.
    Alessandro Maggi
    Public Domain
    Alessandro Maggi
    CMOS implantable Probe
  • We validated our probes by implanting them in explanted leech ganglia and recording spontaneous neural activity. Our data show good probe performance with rms noise less than 10uV and SNR larger than 25dB.
    Alessandro Maggi
    Public Domain
    Alessandro Maggi
    Action Potentials Recordings from Leech Ganglia
  • We implanted our probes in the sensory area of a rat's spinal cord and recorded activity that was mechanically evoked. Our data shows successful recording of compound action potentials which are the result of several hundreds of axons within a sensorial bundle firing together.
    Alessandro Maggi
    Public Domain
    Alessandro Maggi
    Spinal Cord Recordings
  • We mechanically stimulated different areas of a rat's lower body and mapped these anatomical areas onto the white matter located in the dorsal area of the rat's spinal cord, which represents the major sensory section of the spinal cord.
    Alessandro Maggi
    Public Domain
    Alessandro Maggi
    Mapping of the Sensory Area of the Rat's Spinal Cord
